elements.content: Three Cu(II) complexes of tetranuclear [Cu4(cmpy)4(N3)5Cl3] (1), 1D chain [Cu2(cea)2(N3)4] n (2), and two-dimensional layer [Cu5(cmpy)2(N3)10] n (3) were synthesized by controlling the molar ratio of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O, pyCH2Cl·HCl (cmpy·HCl), or H2NCH2CH2Cl·HCl (cea·HCl) and sodium azide. For complexes 1–3, the atom Cl of the ligands (cmpy and cea) is located at the Jahn–Teller axis of Cu(II) with the weak Cu–Cl separations of 2.920(1) - 3.177(1) Å that are shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Cu and Cl atoms, 3.3 Å. The azide ligands coordinate to Cu(II) in the equatorial or basal plane of the coordination pyramid, favoring strong magnetic coupling. The bridging angles of Cu–Nazido–Cu in complexes 1–3 are nearly 101°, corresponding to the presence of global ferromagnetic coupling. The end-to-end azide bridges appear exclusively in complex 3, linking the end-on azide-bridged 1D chains into a 2D layer.

For complexes 1-3, the atom Cl of the ligands (cmpy and cea) is located at the Jahn-Teller axis of Cu(II) with the weak Cu-Cl separations of 2.920(1) - 3.177(1) Å that are shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Cu and Cl atoms, 3.3 Å. The azide ligands coordinate to Cu(II) in the equatorial or basal plane of the coordination pyramid, favoring strong magnetic coupling. The bridging angles of Cu-Nazido-Cu in complexes 1-3 are nearly 101°, corresponding to the presence of global ferromagnetic coupling. The end-to-end azide bridges appear exclusively in complex 3, linking the end-on azide-bridged 1D chains into a 2D layer.

elements.content: Two chlorine-bearing ligands coordinate to Cu(II) ions with the semichelating mode, leaving the basal or equatorial positions of the Cu(II) coordination configuration to azides. The obtained polynuclear, 1D and 2D complexes display global ferromagnetic interaction via the end-on azide bridges.
elements.clean_text: Two chlorine-bearing ligands coordinate to Cu(II) ions with the semichelating mode, leaving the basal or equatorial positions of the Cu(II) coordination configuration to azides. The obtained polynuclear, 1D and 2D complexes display global ferromagnetic interaction via the end-on azide bridges.

elements.content: The azide anion (N3 –) plays an important role in the field of molecular magnetism as a bridging ligand because of its diverse bridging modes and its ability to effectively transmit magnetic coupling. For example, the azide anion can bind up to four metal ions as a monatomic bridge (end-on, EO) and even bind up to six metal ions as two terminal nitrogen ions bridging (end-to-end, EE). Until now, most studies focus on the synthesis and magnetic characterizations of end-on azide-bridged systems because of the presence of ferromagnetic property (high-spin ground state) in most cases. However, the magneto-structural correlations for the azide-Cu(II) system have not been clearly known with a number of available experimental examples.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The azide anion (N3 -) plays an important role in the field of molecular magnetism as a bridging ligand because of its diverse bridging modes and its ability to effectively transmit magnetic coupling. For example, the azide anion can bind up to four metal ions as a monatomic bridge (end-on, EO) and even bind up to six metal ions as two terminal nitrogen ions bridging (end-to-end, EE). Until now, most studies focus on the synthesis and magnetic characterizations of end-on azide-bridged systems because of the presence of ferromagnetic property (high-spin ground state) in most cases. However, the magneto-structural correlations for the azide-Cu(II) system have not been clearly known with a number of available experimental examples.

elements.content: Since copper(II) ion normally possesses four, five or six-coordinate structure due to the Jahn–Teller effect, the coupling of copper complex to azide ion should enable the formation of a novel family of magnetic complexes. However, higher amounts of the coordinating ligands reduce the available coordination sites on Cu(II) for the bridging azide ligand, and thus generally made azide nitrogen atoms occupy the axial positions of Cu(II) coordination sphere. This weak axial coordination would weaken the magnetic coupling and frequently give rise to antiferromagnetic coupling. Therefore, the change in the amount of the capping ligands should in principle change the structural pattern and even the magnetism of Cu–azido systems.
elements.clean_text: Since copper(II) ion normally possesses four, five or six-coordinate structure due to the Jahn-Teller effect, the coupling of copper complex to azide ion should enable the formation of a novel family of magnetic complexes. However, higher amounts of the coordinating ligands reduce the available coordination sites on Cu(II) for the bridging azide ligand, and thus generally made azide nitrogen atoms occupy the axial positions of Cu(II) coordination sphere. This weak axial coordination would weaken the magnetic coupling and frequently give rise to antiferromagnetic coupling. Therefore, the change in the amount of the capping ligands should in principle change the structural pattern and even the magnetism of Cu-azido systems.

elements.content: Among the amine Cu(II) azides, pyridine and its modified analogs along with the chelating ethylenediamine, 2,2′-bipyridine and their analogs have been widely used. These amine ligands usually coordinate to Cu(II) ions with their nitrogen atom situated at the equatorial or basal sites, thus frequently making the azide ligands occupy the axial positions. To avoid the axial coordination of the bridging azido ion, we studied a new type of Cl-substituted amine ligands, 2-chloromethyl-pyridine (cmpy) and 2-chloroethyl-amine (cea) (Scheme ). Considering the potential coordination of the chlorine atom, the ligands cmpy and cea can be taken as semichelating ligands, which has been proven by the mononuclear complex [Cu(cmpy)2Cl2]. It is anticipated that the chlorine atoms most likely occupy the axial positions, favoring the equatorial coordination of azides toward Cu(II). Herein, we describe three new Cu(II)–azide complexes controlled by the semichelating ligands.

To avoid the axial coordination of the bridging azido ion, we studied a new type of Cl-substituted amine ligands, 2-chloromethyl-pyridine (cmpy) and 2-chloroethyl-amine (cea) (Scheme ). Considering the potential coordination of the chlorine atom, the ligands cmpy and cea can be taken as semichelating ligands, which has been proven by the mononuclear complex [Cu(cmpy)2Cl2]. It is anticipated that the chlorine atoms most likely occupy the axial positions, favoring the equatorial coordination of azides toward Cu(II). Herein, we describe three new Cu(II)-azide complexes controlled by the semichelating ligands.

elements.content: 2-Chloromethyl-pyridine hydrochloride (cmpy·HCl), 2-chloroethylamine hydrochloride (cea·HCl), and sodium azide (NaN3) were used as received without further purification. Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O) was synthesized by dissolving excessive basic cupric carbonate [xCuCO3·yCu(OH)2] (10 g) in perchloric acid solution (70%, 20 mL). The mixture was carefully heated with stirring for half an hour and filtered, giving crystals of copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Synthesis

2-Chloromethyl-pyridine hydrochloride (cmpy⋅HCl), 2-chloroethylamine hydrochloride (cea⋅HCl), and sodium azide (NaN3) were used as received without further purification. Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O) was synthesized by dissolving excessive basic cupric carbonate [xCuCO3⋅yCu(OH)2] (10 g) in perchloric acid solution (70%, 20 mL). The mixture was carefully heated with stirring for half an hour and filtered, giving crystals of copper(II) perchlorate hexahydrate.

elements.content:
Caution! Azide salts of metal complexes are potentially explosive. They should be handled in small quantities with care.

[Cu<sub>4</sub>(cmpy)<sub>4</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>5</sub>Cl<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

cmpy·HCl (98.4 mg, 0.60 mmol) and Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (111 mg, 0.30 mmol) were dissolved in CH3OH (15 mL). To the green resultant solution, NaN3 (58.5 mg, 0.90 mmol) in methanol (15 mL) was added dropwise under stirring. The solution turned brown, and stirring continued for additional 10 min. The resultant solution was allowed to crystallize in refrigerator for several hours, and black crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: ∼50%. Main IR bands (cm–1): v(NN, azide), 2071vs; v(CN), 1604s; 1570s; 1483s; 1446; 1284vs; 1157; 1027.

elements.content: cea·HCl (46.4 mg, 0.40 mmol) and Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (74 mg, 0.20 mmol) were dissolved in CH3OH (15 mL). To the resultant blue solution, NaN3 (39.0 mg, 0.60 mmol) in methanol (15 mL) was added dropwise under stirring. The solution turned brown, and stirring continued for additional 10 min. The resultant solution was allowed to slowly evaporate at ambient temperature for several days, and dark blue crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 70%. Main IR bands (cm–1): v(NN, azide), 2079vs, 2037vs; 1271; 1114; 923.

elements.content: IR spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna-IR 750 spectrometer in the 4000–650 cm–1 region. The room temperature powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed over the angular range 5° < 2θ < 40° with a 0.02° step on a Bruker D8-Discover high-resolution diffractometer with Cu Kα source (λ = 1.5406 Å). Temperature- and field-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer from 2 to 300 K. Some crystals of complexes 1–3 were collected and used for magnetic measurements. The experimental susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal’s Tables).
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

IR spectra were performed on a Nicolet Magna-IR 750 spectrometer in the 4000-650 cm-1 region. The room temperature powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed over the angular range 5° < 2θ < 40° with a 0.02° step on a Bruker D8-Discover high-resolution diffractometer with Cu Kα source (λ = 1.5406 Å). Temperature- and field-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer from 2 to 300 K. Some crystals of complexes 1-3 were collected and used for magnetic measurements. The experimental susceptibilities were corrected for the diamagnetism of the constituent atoms (Pascal's Tables).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct method SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL-97) on F 2. Hydrogen atoms were added geometrically and refined using a riding model.
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct method SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL-97) on F 2. Hydrogen atoms were added geometrically and refined using a riding model.

elements.content: All the complexes (1–3) were obtained from the reaction of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O, two molar equivalents of cmpy·HCl or cea·HCl with an excess of NaN3 in MeOH. NaN3 was exhausted by neutralization of excessive cmpy·HCl, yielding the known mononuclear complex [Cu(cmpy)2Cl2]. When a larger amount of NaN3 was used, azide-bridged polynuclear complexes 1 and 2 together with the 2D complex 3 were obtained. On the basis of the crystal data of complexes 1–3, it can be found that the chlorine atoms of cmpy or cea are indeed involved in shielding the axial positions of the Cu(II) coordination sphere, leaving the equatorial/pyramidal coordination site for azide ligands to occupy as expected. In complex 1, chloride anions from cmpy·HCl are coordinated with the Cu(II) ion, affording a neutral tetranuclear complex. The large excess of NaN3 removes the capping cmpy ligands around Cu(II), affording more coordination sites for azide anions to occupy. Therefore, a 2D polymeric complex (3) is formed. In the process of assembly of the 0D–2D Cu(II)-azides, the peculiar coordination of the semichelate ligands is decisive. XRD measurements show that the experimental data are in good agreement with that calculated from the single-crystal diffraction data, suggestive of that the samples are pure (Figures S1–S3, ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and IR

All the complexes (1-3) were obtained from the reaction of Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, two molar equivalents of cmpy⋅HCl or cea⋅HCl with an excess of NaN3 in MeOH. NaN3 was exhausted by neutralization of excessive cmpy⋅HCl, yielding the known mononuclear complex [Cu(cmpy)2Cl2]. When a larger amount of NaN3 was used, azide-bridged polynuclear complexes 1 and 2 together with the 2D complex 3 were obtained. On the basis of the crystal data of complexes 1-3, it can be found that the chlorine atoms of cmpy or cea are indeed involved in shielding the axial positions of the Cu(II) coordination sphere, leaving the equatorial/pyramidal coordination site for azide ligands to occupy as expected. In complex 1, chloride anions from cmpy⋅HCl are coordinated with the Cu(II) ion, affording a neutral tetranuclear complex. The large excess of NaN3 removes the capping cmpy ligands around Cu(II), affording more coordination sites for azide anions to occupy. Therefore, a 2D polymeric complex (3) is formed. In the process of assembly of the 0D-2D Cu(II)-azides, the peculiar coordination of the semichelate ligands is decisive. XRD measurements show that the experimental data are in good agreement with that calculated from the single-crystal diffraction data, suggestive of that the samples are pure (Figures S1-S3, ).

elements.content: The IR spectra of the complexes are similar (Figures S4–S6, ) and show the peak of the ν(NN) stretching bands in 2071 cm–1 for 1, 2079 cm–1 and 2037 cm–1 for 2, 2089 cm–1 for 3, suggestive of the presence of end-on azide anions. The peak at 1604, 1570, and 1484 cm–1 of 1 and also 1604, 1571, and 1485 cm–1 of 3 can be reasonably attributed to the ν(CN) and ν(CC) of the six-membered pyridine rings in cmpy.

The peak at 1604, 1570, and 1484 cm-1 of 1 and also 1604, 1571, and 1485 cm-1 of 3 can be reasonably attributed to the ν(CN) and ν(CC) of the six-membered pyridine rings in cmpy.

elements.content:
Crystal data and structure refinement details for compounds 1–3 are listed in Table , and important bond distances and bond angles of complexes 1–3 are collected in Table .

Structure Description of [Cu<sub>4</sub>(cmpy)<sub>4</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>5</sub>Cl<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

Complex 1 possesses a linear tetranuclear structure, where four Cu(II) ions are bridged by five end-on azide ligands and a chloride ion (Figure ). The Cu(1) and Cu(2) ions at the ends of the linear molecule is doubly end-on azide-bridged, while the central Cu(2) and Cu(2A) ions are connected by an end-on azide and a chloride ion. Because of the Jahn–Teller effect, the coordination environments of both Cu(1) and Cu(2) are elongated octahedral. The axial bond distances around Cu(1) are 2.436(2) Å for Cu(1)–O(1) and 3.176(1) Å for Cu(1)–Cl(1), apparently longer than the four equatorial bonds. Four nitrogen atoms coordinate to Cu(2) in the equatorial plane with the bond distances, and two chlorine atoms occupy the axial positions with the Cu(2)–Cl bond distances of 2.694(1) Å [Cu(2)–Cl(4)] and 3.042(1) Å [Cu(2)–Cl(2)]. The Cu–Cl bond distances are shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Cu and Cl atoms, 3.3 Å. Therefore, the bridging azide nitrogen atoms all occupy the equatorial positions, and the bridging chloride anion (Cl(4)) is situated at the axial sites of Cu(II). The bridging Cu–Nazide–Cu bond angles are 103.84(10)° for Cu(1)–N(4)–Cu(2), 101.35(9)° for Cu(1)–N(1)–Cu(2) and 117.50(17)° for Cu(2)–N(7)–Cu(2A). In the doubly azide-bridged Cu(II) unit, the N(1) atom bridges two Cu(II) ions with larger Cu–Nbr bond distances in comparison with N(4).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions

Crystal data and structure refinement details for compounds 1-3 are listed in Table , and important bond distances and bond angles of complexes 1-3 are collected in Table .

Structure Description of [Cu4(cmpy)4(N3)5Cl3] (1)

Complex 1 possesses a linear tetranuclear structure, where four Cu(II) ions are bridged by five end-on azide ligands and a chloride ion (Figure ). The Cu(1) and Cu(2) ions at the ends of the linear molecule is doubly end-on azide-bridged, while the central Cu(2) and Cu(2A) ions are connected by an end-on azide and a chloride ion. Because of the Jahn-Teller effect, the coordination environments of both Cu(1) and Cu(2) are elongated octahedral. The axial bond distances around Cu(1) are 2.436(2) Å for Cu(1)-O(1) and 3.176(1) Å for Cu(1)-Cl(1), apparently longer than the four equatorial bonds. Four nitrogen atoms coordinate to Cu(2) in the equatorial plane with the bond distances, and two chlorine atoms occupy the axial positions with the Cu(2)-Cl bond distances of 2.694(1) Å [Cu(2)-Cl(4)] and 3.042(1) Å [Cu(2)-Cl(2)]. The Cu-Cl bond distances are shorter than the sum of van der Waals radii of Cu and Cl atoms, 3.3 Å. Therefore, the bridging azide nitrogen atoms all occupy the equatorial positions, and the bridging chloride anion (Cl(4)) is situated at the axial sites of Cu(II). The bridging Cu-Nazide-Cu bond angles are 103.84(10)° for Cu(1)-N(4)-Cu(2), 101.35(9)° for Cu(1)-N(1)-Cu(2) and 117.50(17)° for Cu(2)-N(7)-Cu(2A). In the doubly azide-bridged Cu(II) unit, the N(1) atom bridges two Cu(II) ions with larger Cu-Nbr bond distances in comparison with N(4).

Chainlike structure of complex 2. The violet bonds represent the weak axial Cu–N/Cl contacts.
elements.clean_text: 2  Chainlike structure of complex 2. The violet bonds represent the weak axial Cu-N/Cl contacts.

elements.content: Complex 2 is a 1D coordination assembly of dinuclear Cu(II) units connected by end-on azide anions. The repeating dinuclear unit contains two Cu(II) ions (Cu(1) and Cu(1A)) bridged by two end-on azide groups (Figure ), and the dinuclear units are connected via the weak axial Cu–Nazide coordination interactions. The coordination environments of Cu(II) are identical, and are elongated octahedral with four nitrogen atoms (N(1), N(1A), N(4), and N(7)) situated at the equatorial positions and one chlorine atom (Cl(1)) and the nitrogen atom (N(4B)) at the axial sites. The equatorial Cu–N bond distances range from 1.997(2) Å [Cu(1)–N(4)] to 2.025(2) Å [Cu(1)–N(1A)], and the axial bond distances are 2.418(2) Å for Cu(1)–N(4B) and 2.920(1) Å for Cu(1)–Cl(1). The bridging bond angles for Cu(1)–N(1)–Cu(1A) and Cu(1)–N(1A)–Cu(1A) are 100.29(8)°, and the equatorial-axial bridging angles for Cu(1)–N(4)–Cu(1B) and Cu(1)–N(4B)–Cu(1B) are 96.36(7)°. A unidentate tetrazolate ligand Cu(II) complex has an azido-bridged 1D chain structure similar to that of complex 2.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of [Cu2(cea)2(N3)4] n  (2)

Complex 2 is a 1D coordination assembly of dinuclear Cu(II) units connected by end-on azide anions. The repeating dinuclear unit contains two Cu(II) ions (Cu(1) and Cu(1A)) bridged by two end-on azide groups (Figure ), and the dinuclear units are connected via the weak axial Cu-Nazide coordination interactions. The coordination environments of Cu(II) are identical, and are elongated octahedral with four nitrogen atoms (N(1), N(1A), N(4), and N(7)) situated at the equatorial positions and one chlorine atom (Cl(1)) and the nitrogen atom (N(4B)) at the axial sites. The equatorial Cu-N bond distances range from 1.997(2) Å [Cu(1)-N(4)] to 2.025(2) Å [Cu(1)-N(1A)], and the axial bond distances are 2.418(2) Å for Cu(1)-N(4B) and 2.920(1) Å for Cu(1)-Cl(1). The bridging bond angles for Cu(1)-N(1)-Cu(1A) and Cu(1)-N(1A)-Cu(1A) are 100.29(8)°, and the equatorial-axial bridging angles for Cu(1)-N(4)-Cu(1B) and Cu(1)-N(4B)-Cu(1B) are 96.36(7)°. A unidentate tetrazolate ligand Cu(II) complex has an azido-bridged 1D chain structure similar to that of complex 2.

elements.content: The 1D chains are not isolated, but are connected by interchain N–H···Cl hydrogen bonds with the H···Cl separation of 2.877 Å (Figure S7, ). All chlorine atoms are involved in the hydrogen-bonding interaction, and therefore a 3D molecular structure is formed. The nearest interchain Cu(II)–Cu(II) separation is 7.501 Å.
elements.clean_text: The 1D chains are not isolated, but are connected by interchain N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bonds with the H⋅⋅⋅Cl separation of 2.877 Å (Figure S7, ). All chlorine atoms are involved in the hydrogen-bonding interaction, and therefore a 3D molecular structure is formed. The nearest interchain Cu(II)-Cu(II) separation is 7.501 Å.

elements.content: The structure of complex 2 is markedly different from that of 2D complex [Cu(en)(N3)2] in which the adjacent neutral [Cu(en)(N3)2] units are connected by basal-apical end-on and end-to-end azide ligands. These results show that the semichelating ligands can modulate the assembly modes of the Cu(II) azide complexes.
elements.clean_text: The structure of complex 2 is markedly different from that of 2D complex [Cu(en)(N3)2] in which the adjacent neutral [Cu(en)(N3)2] units are connected by basal-apical end-on and end-to-end azide ligands. These results show that the semichelating ligands can modulate the assembly modes of the Cu(II) azide complexes.

elements.content: Upper: 1D chain structure with the Cu5 repeating unit for complex 3 (The violet and red bonds represent the weak intrachain Cu–N/Cl and interchain Cu–N coordination, respectively). Lower: 2D layered structure of complex 3 (The red bonds stand for the weak Cu–N contacts that link 1D chains into a 2D layer).
elements.clean_text: 3  Upper: 1D chain structure with the Cu5 repeating unit for complex 3 (The violet and red bonds represent the weak intrachain Cu-N/Cl and interchain Cu-N coordination, respectively). Lower: 2D layered structure of complex 3 (The red bonds stand for the weak Cu-N contacts that link 1D chains into a 2D layer).

elements.content: Complex 3 is a 2D coordination assembly of azide-bridged pentanuclear Cu(II) units (Cu(1), Cu(1B), Cu(2), Cu(3), and Cu(2A) in Figure ). The repeating Cu5 unit can be described as end-on azide-bridged trinuclear group (Cu(2)–Cu(3)–Cu(2A)) along with an equatorial-axial end-on azide-bridged dinuclear group (Cu(1)–Cu(1B)) (Figure , upper). The trinuclear and the dinuclear moieties alternate, giving rise to a one-dimensional chain. The adjacent chains are connected by the μ1,1,1,3-azide bridging ligands, yielding a two-dimensional layer (Figure , lower). Except Cu(3) with a square planar coordination environment, other Cu(II) ions exhibit an elongated octahedral configuration. One cmpy ligand chelates to Cu(1) with the chlorine atom at the Jahn–Teller axial position (Cu(1)–Cl(1) = 2.932(2) Å). For Cu(2), the four short equatorial Cu–N coordination bonds are nearly 2.0 Å, and the two longer axial bond distances are 2.453(7) Å and 2.508(7) Å. For square planar Cu(3), the Cu–N bond distances are in the range from 1.968(6) Å [Cu(3)–N(4)] to 1.979(6) Å [Cu(3)–N(13)]. Complex 3 is reminiscent of the 2D complex [Cu5(bzp)2(N3)10] n (bzp =2-Benzoylpyridyl), where the oxygen atom of the bzp ligand similarly occupies the apical position. Albeit similar formula and ligation, [Cu5(bzp)2(N3)10] n has an end-on azide-bridged 2D layer based on linear Cu5 units.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of [Cu5(cmpy)2(N3)10] n  (3)

Complex 3 is a 2D coordination assembly of azide-bridged pentanuclear Cu(II) units (Cu(1), Cu(1B), Cu(2), Cu(3), and Cu(2A) in Figure ). The repeating Cu5 unit can be described as end-on azide-bridged trinuclear group (Cu(2)-Cu(3)-Cu(2A)) along with an equatorial-axial end-on azide-bridged dinuclear group (Cu(1)-Cu(1B)) (Figure , upper). The trinuclear and the dinuclear moieties alternate, giving rise to a one-dimensional chain. The adjacent chains are connected by the μ1,1,1,3-azide bridging ligands, yielding a two-dimensional layer (Figure , lower). Except Cu(3) with a square planar coordination environment, other Cu(II) ions exhibit an elongated octahedral configuration. One cmpy ligand chelates to Cu(1) with the chlorine atom at the Jahn-Teller axial position (Cu(1)-Cl(1) = 2.932(2) Å). For Cu(2), the four short equatorial Cu-N coordination bonds are nearly 2.0 Å, and the two longer axial bond distances are 2.453(7) Å and 2.508(7) Å. For square planar Cu(3), the Cu-N bond distances are in the range from 1.968(6) Å [Cu(3)-N(4)] to 1.979(6) Å [Cu(3)-N(13)]. Complex 3 is reminiscent of the 2D complex [Cu5(bzp)2(N3)10] n  (bzp =2-Benzoylpyridyl), where the oxygen atom of the bzp ligand similarly occupies the apical position. Albeit similar formula and ligation, [Cu5(bzp)2(N3)10] n  has an end-on azide-bridged 2D layer based on linear Cu5 units.

elements.content: In summary, complexes 1–3 are interesting examples of azide-bridged Cu(II) complexes with the molecular structures of 0D-2D. The present result further suggests that the molar ratio of ligands to Cu(II) is the most important factor affecting the structures. The molar ratio of 1:1 results in low-dimensional structures in complexes 1 and 2, while the molar ratio of 2:5 gives rise to the 2D structure in complex 3. It is worth mentioning that the complex [Cu6(N-Ipren)2(N3)12] (N-Ipren = N-isopropylethylenediamine) with the molar ratio of 1:3 has a 3D molecular structure.

The present result further suggests that the molar ratio of ligands to Cu(II) is the most important factor affecting the structures. The molar ratio of 1:1 results in low-dimensional structures in complexes 1 and 2, while the molar ratio of 2:5 gives rise to the 2D structure in complex 3. It is worth mentioning that the complex [Cu6(N-Ipren)2(N3)12] (N-Ipren = N-isopropylethylenediamine) with the molar ratio of 1:3 has a 3D molecular structure.

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1–3 have been measured in an applied magnetic field of 2 kOe for complexes 1 and 2 or 5 kOe for complex 3. Figures and show the χm T vs T plots for complexes 1–3, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1-3 have been measured in an applied magnetic field of 2 kOe for complexes 1 and 2 or 5 kOe for complex 3. Figures  and  show the χm T vs T plots for complexes 1-3, respectively.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of χm T for complexes 1 (per Cu4) and 2 (per Cu2). The solid line represents the best fit results using the parameters discussed in the text.
elements.clean_text: 4  Temperature dependence of χm T for complexes 1 (per Cu4) and 2 (per Cu2). The solid line represents the best fit results using the parameters discussed in the text.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 2 are similar, and the plot of χm T versus T for both complexes is shown in Figure . The χm T product per Cu4 for complex 1 and per Cu2 for complex 2 is equal to 1.6 emu K mol–1 and 0.85 emu K mol–1 at 300 K, slightly higher than the spin-only value of 1.5 emu K mol–1 and 0.75 emu K mol–1 for a tetranuclear and a dinuclear Cu(II) ion (S = 1/2) system with g = 2.0, respectively. With the decrease of the temperature, χm T first increases gradually and then decreases until 2 K. The maximum value of 6.0 emu K mol–1 occurs at 56 K for complex 1, while 0.90 emu K mol–1 at 80 K for complex 2. The χm –1 versus T plot (300–50 K) obeys the Curie–Weiss law with a positive Weiss constant of θ = 7.82 K for complex 1 and 6.5 K for complex 2. This magnetic behavior suggests the presence of global ferromagnetic interaction with the cooperation of weak intermolecular antiferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 2 are similar, and the plot of χm T versus T for both complexes is shown in Figure . The χm T product per Cu4 for complex 1 and per Cu2 for complex 2 is equal to 1.6 emu K mol-1 and 0.85 emu K mol-1 at 300 K, slightly higher than the spin-only value of 1.5 emu K mol-1 and 0.75 emu K mol-1 for a tetranuclear and a dinuclear Cu(II) ion (S = 1/2) system with g = 2.0, respectively. With the decrease of the temperature, χm T first increases gradually and then decreases until 2 K. The maximum value of 6.0 emu K mol-1 occurs at 56 K for complex 1, while 0.90 emu K mol-1 at 80 K for complex 2. The χm -1 versus T plot (300-50 K) obeys the Curie-Weiss law with a positive Weiss constant of θ = 7.82 K for complex 1 and 6.5 K for complex 2. This magnetic behavior suggests the presence of global ferromagnetic interaction with the cooperation of weak intermolecular antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: To evaluate the strength of intra/inter-moleculer magnetic coupling (J 1, J 2 and zJ′), equation (, eq 1) based on the spin Hamiltonian for linear Cu1–Cu2–Cu2A–Cu1A complexes Ĥ = − 2 J 1 ( Ŝ Cu 1 · Ŝ Cu 2 + Ŝ Cu 1 A · Ŝ Cu 2 A ) − 2 J 2 Ŝ Cu 2 · Ŝ Cu 2 A + g β H Ŝ − z J ′ ⟨ S z T ⟩ Ŝ z T has been used to fit the experimental magnetic data, where the Cu(II) ions are designated according to Figure . The best-fit parameters are J 1 = 17.0(5) cm–1, J 2 = −3.7(1) cm–1, g = 2.06(2), and zJ′ = −0.98(3) cm–1. The fitting results show that the intramolecular magnetic coupling via the end-on azide bridges is different, i.e. ferromagnetic for the external Cu(II) ions and antiferromagnetic for the central Cu(II) ions. The bridging Cu–Nazide–Cu bond angles, 101.35(9)° and 103.84(10)° for the ferromagnetic exchange (J 1), and 117.50(17)° for the antiferromagnetic coupling (J 2) are in good agreement with the previous assumption that end-on doubly azide-bridged Cu2 dimer should exhibit ferromagnetic coupling with Cu–N–Cu bond angles below the calculated critical angle of 104° or the experimental value of 108°.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the strength of intra/inter-moleculer magnetic coupling (J 1, J 2 and zJ'), equation (, eq 1) based on the spin Hamiltonian for linear Cu1-Cu2-Cu2A-Cu1A complexes  Ĥ = - 2   J   1    (   Ŝ   Cu 1   ⋅   Ŝ   Cu 2   +   Ŝ   Cu 1 A   ⋅   Ŝ   Cu 2 A   )  - 2   J   2     Ŝ   Cu 2   ⋅   Ŝ   Cu 2 A   + g β H Ŝ - z J '  ⟨   S   z   T   ⟩    Ŝ   z   T    has been used to fit the experimental magnetic data, where the Cu(II) ions are designated according to Figure . The best-fit parameters are J 1 = 17.0(5) cm-1, J 2 = -3.7(1) cm-1, g = 2.06(2), and zJ' = -0.98(3) cm-1. The fitting results show that the intramolecular magnetic coupling via the end-on azide bridges is different, i.e. ferromagnetic for the external Cu(II) ions and antiferromagnetic for the central Cu(II) ions. The bridging Cu-Nazide-Cu bond angles, 101.35(9)° and 103.84(10)° for the ferromagnetic exchange (J 1), and 117.50(17)° for the antiferromagnetic coupling (J 2) are in good agreement with the previous assumption that end-on doubly azide-bridged Cu2 dimer should exhibit ferromagnetic coupling with Cu-N-Cu bond angles below the calculated critical angle of 104° or the experimental value of 108°.

elements.content: From the structural point of view for this one-dimension complex (2), the in-plane end-on azido bridge between Cu(1) and Cu(1A) accounts for the dominant magnetic pathway. The weak magnetic coupling between the dimer molecules through the equatorial-axial end-on azide bridges was described by using the mean-field approximation method. A reasonable fit (2–300 K) can be obtained for interacting binuclear units applying the conventional Hamiltonian Ĥ = −2JŜ cu1·Ŝ cu1A introducing an interdimer zJ′ term. χ m = χ d / [ 1 − χ d ( 2 z J ′ / N g 2 β 2 ) ] χ d = 2 ( N g 2 β 2 / k T ) / [ 3 + exp ( − 2 J / k T ) ]

elements.content: The best fit parameters are J = 28(2) cm–1, zJ′ = −4.8(1) cm–1, and g = 2.11(1) for complex 2. In complex 2, the symmetric end-on azido bridging Cu(1)–N(1)–Cu(1A) angle of 100.29(8)° (below 104°) along with the basal Cu(1)–N(1) and Cu(1A)-N(1) bonds of 2.025(2) Å corresponds to the ferromagnetic exchange. The interdimer end-on bridging bonds of Cu(1)–N(4)–Cu(1B) (96.36(7)°) are asymmetric with the equatorial-axial coordination, making the magnetic exchange (J′) via Cu(1)–N(4)–Cu(1B) weakly antiferromagnetic.

elements.content: DFT calculations show that the out-of-plane displacement of the EO azido groups contributes little to the strength of the magnetic coupling, and therefore the Cu–Nazido bond distances, the Cu–N–Cu bond angles and the distortion of the coordination basal plane for square pyramidal Cu(II) should be considered. Table collects the structures and magnetism of end-on azide-bridged Cu(II) complexes, where the bridging azide ligands are situated at the equatorial or basal plane of Cu(II) coordination polyhedron, that is, symmetric azide bridging. In the complexes, the Cu–Nazido bond distances are in the range 1.889–2.142 Å with the Cu–Nazido–Cu bridging angles of 96.2–107.0°. The ferromagnetic property has been more frequently observed, and the two antiferromagnetic cases have the Cu–Nazido–Cu bridging angles close to 104.0°, the theoretical critical angle (Figure based on the data in Table ). Moreover, it can be seen that the strong ferromagnetic coupling generally corresponds to complexes with small Cu–Nazido bond distances and Cu–Nazido–Cu bridging angles, and the distortion parameter evaluating the distortion of square pyramidal toward trigonal bipyramidal environment is only a minor factor affecting magnetic coupling.

The magnetic coupling constant in complex 1 is moderate, which would be due to the presence of two different Cu–N–Cu bond angles, one of which is close to the critical angle of 104°. However, the two complexes have the Cu–N–Cu bond angles less than 104.3°, showing antiferromagnetic coupling. This result indicates the complexity of the magnetic coupling, and more examples with antiferromagnetic coupling are expected to clarify this.

elements.content: The plot of χm T versus T for 3 per CuII 5 unit is shown in Figure . The room temperature χm T value of 2.41 emu K mol–1 is higher than the theoretical value of 1.875 emu K mol–1 for five uncoupled CuII ions (assuming g = 2.0). The χm T value gradually increases upon decreasing temperature from 300 K and reaches a maximum value of 7.82 emu K mol–1 at 4 K. Further cooling decreases the χm T value to 6.48 emu K mol–1 at 2 K. The 1/χm versus T plot (300–80 K) obeys the Curie–Weiss law with a positive Weiss constant of θ = 31.4 K. The nature of the χm T versus T plot and the positive θ suggest a dominant ferromagnetic exchange among the five CuII ions through azido bridges.

elements.clean_text: 2  Magnetic Exchanges via the End-on Azide Bridges in Complex 3       a The broken lines represent the weak axial coordination.

elements.content:
The broken lines represent the weak axial coordination.

For the two-dimensional complex 3, the fit to the magnetic susceptibilities is not possible. Nevertheless, the qualitative analyses of the magnetic coupling can be made. Neglecting the equatorial-axial end-on azide bridging pathways and the end-to-end azide bridges, the in-plane end-on azide-bridged Cu(II) ions form a 1D chain with the pentanuclear Cu5 repeating unit (Scheme ). In the Cu5 unit, the end-on azide ligands bridge adjacent Cu(2)–Cu(3) and Cu(3)–Cu(2A) ions with the Cu–N–Cu bond angles in the range 101.0(3)–101.2(3)°, corresponding to the ferromagnetic realm. The magnetic coupling between Cu(2) and Cu(1) should be antiferromagnetic with the Cu–N–Cu bond angles in the range 109.8(3)–113.7(3)°. Under the circumstances, ferrimagnetic behavior is expected, however, overall ferromagnetic property is observed. This phenomenon may be due to the presence of the Cu(1)–Cu(1A) magnetic coupling via the out-of-plane end-on azide bridges that is usually antiferromagnetic. Therefore, spin frustration occurs, making the spins on Cu(1) and Cu(1A) somewhat cant.

For the two-dimensional complex 3, the fit to the magnetic susceptibilities is not possible. Nevertheless, the qualitative analyses of the magnetic coupling can be made. Neglecting the equatorial-axial end-on azide bridging pathways and the end-to-end azide bridges, the in-plane end-on azide-bridged Cu(II) ions form a 1D chain with the pentanuclear Cu5 repeating unit (Scheme ). In the Cu5 unit, the end-on azide ligands bridge adjacent Cu(2)-Cu(3) and Cu(3)-Cu(2A) ions with the Cu-N-Cu bond angles in the range 101.0(3)-101.2(3)°, corresponding to the ferromagnetic realm. The magnetic coupling between Cu(2) and Cu(1) should be antiferromagnetic with the Cu-N-Cu bond angles in the range 109.8(3)-113.7(3)°. Under the circumstances, ferrimagnetic behavior is expected, however, overall ferromagnetic property is observed. This phenomenon may be due to the presence of the Cu(1)-Cu(1A) magnetic coupling via the out-of-plane end-on azide bridges that is usually antiferromagnetic. Therefore, spin frustration occurs, making the spins on Cu(1) and Cu(1A) somewhat cant.

elements.content: The adjacent chains are linked by the μ1,1,1,3-azide bridges. Among the four Cu–Nazide coordination bonds only one strong Cu–N bond is present, and the other three Cu–N bonds are involved in axial coordination. Thus, the interchain magnetic coupling should be very weak, either ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic. The weak interchain and interlayer magnetic interactions preclude the occurrence of long-range magnetic ordering in complex 3, which is verified by the field-cooled magnetization (FCM) measurement (Figure S8, ).

elements.content: The field dependence of the magnetization (0–50 kOe) of complexes 1–3 was measured at 2.0 K, as shown in Figure S9 (). The magnetization of complexes 1 and 2 shows linear increase with the increase of the applied magnetic field, reaching the value of 1.63 Nβ for complex 1 and 0.64 Nβ for complex 2. This suggests the low-spin ground state for the complexes because of the presence of appreciable antiferromagnetic coupling within the molecule/chain. The rapid increase in the magnetization at low field for 3 is typical of the presence of ferromagnetic coupling. The saturation magnetization value of 4.58 Nβ for complex 3 is lower than the theoretical value of 5.0 Nβ, suggestive of the presence of spin canting.

elements.content: The present work describes a strategy of designing azide-bridged Cu(II) complexes based on the Jahn–Teller effect for Cu(II). Semichelating ligands are used with weak coordinating chlorine atom in the ligands. Three azide-bridged Cu(II) complexes containing strong Cu(II)–Nazide contacts are obtained by tuning the molar ratio of Cu(II) to azide and the pH of the reaction solutions. The magnetic properties are consistent with the previous assumption that the Cu–Nazide–Cu bond angle is decisive in magnetic coupling via the azide bridges.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The present work describes a strategy of designing azide-bridged Cu(II) complexes based on the Jahn-Teller effect for Cu(II). Semichelating ligands are used with weak coordinating chlorine atom in the ligands. Three azide-bridged Cu(II) complexes containing strong Cu(II)-Nazide contacts are obtained by tuning the molar ratio of Cu(II) to azide and the pH of the reaction solutions. The magnetic properties are consistent with the previous assumption that the Cu-Nazide-Cu bond angle is decisive in magnetic coupling via the azide bridges.

elements.content: IR spectra for complexes 1–3, powdered XRD spectra for complexes 1–3, hydrogen-bonded 3D structure of complex 2, field dependence of magnetization of complex 1–3 at 2.0 K, FCM plot for complex 3 and an X-ray crystallographic file (CIF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Caution! Azide salts of metal complexes are potentially explosive. They should be handled in small quantities with care.

[Cu<sub>4</sub>(cmpy)<sub>4</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>5</sub>Cl<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

cmpy·HCl (98.4 mg, 0.60 mmol) and Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (111 mg, 0.30 mmol) were dissolved in CH3OH (15 mL). To the green resultant solution, NaN3 (58.5 mg, 0.90 mmol) in methanol (15 mL) was added dropwise under stirring. The solution turned brown, and stirring continued for additional 10 min. The resultant solution was allowed to crystallize in refrigerator for several hours, and black crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: ∼50%. Main IR bands (cm–1): v(NN, azide), 2071vs; v(CN), 1604s; 1570s; 1483s; 1446; 1284vs; 1157; 1027.

[Cu<sub>2</sub>(cea)<sub>2</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

cea·HCl (46.4 mg, 0.40 mmol) and Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (74 mg, 0.20 mmol) were dissolved in CH3OH (15 mL). To the resultant blue solution, NaN3 (39.0 mg, 0.60 mmol) in methanol (15 mL) was added dropwise under stirring. The solution turned brown, and stirring continued for additional 10 min. The resultant solution was allowed to slowly evaporate at ambient temperature for several days, and dark blue crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 70%. Main IR bands (cm–1): v(NN, azide), 2079vs, 2037vs; 1271; 1114; 923.

[Cu<sub>5</sub>(cmpy)<sub>2</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>10</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

The synthetic method of complex 3 was similar to that of complex 1, by using more excess NaN3 (78.0 mg, 1.2 mmol) in methanol (20 mL) instead. Well-shaped black crystals of 3 were obtained. Yield: 50%. v(NN), 2089br; v(CN), 1604s; 1571s; 1486s; 1333; 1279vs; 1027.

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic properties of complexes 1 and 2 are similar, and the plot of χm T versus T for both complexes is shown in Figure . The χm T product per Cu4 for complex 1 and per Cu2 for complex 2 is equal to 1.6 emu K mol–1 and 0.85 emu K mol–1 at 300 K, slightly higher than the spin-only value of 1.5 emu K mol–1 and 0.75 emu K mol–1 for a tetranuclear and a dinuclear Cu(II) ion (S = 1/2) system with g = 2.0, respectively. With the decrease of the temperature, χm T first increases gradually and then decreases until 2 K. The maximum value of 6.0 emu K mol–1 occurs at 56 K for complex 1, while 0.90 emu K mol–1 at 80 K for complex 2. The χm –1 versus T plot (300–50 K) obeys the Curie–Weiss law with a positive Weiss constant of θ = 7.82 K for complex 1 and 6.5 K for complex 2. This magnetic behavior suggests the presence of global ferromagnetic interaction with the cooperation of weak intermolecular antiferromagnetic coupling.

The plot of χm T versus T for 3 per CuII 5 unit is shown in Figure . The room temperature χm T value of 2.41 emu K mol–1 is higher than the theoretical value of 1.875 emu K mol–1 for five uncoupled CuII ions (assuming g = 2.0). The χm T value gradually increases upon decreasing temperature from 300 K and reaches a maximum value of 7.82 emu K mol–1 at 4 K. Further cooling decreases the χm T value to 6.48 emu K mol–1 at 2 K. The 1/χm versus T plot (300–80 K) obeys the Curie–Weiss law with a positive Weiss constant of θ = 31.4 K. The nature of the χm T versus T plot and the positive θ suggest a dominant ferromagnetic exchange among the five CuII ions through azido bridges.
